awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Marino Romero is "An e-positivity phenomenon". The host institution for the fellowship is University of Pennsylvania and the sponsoring scientist is James Haglund.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A symmetric function is said to be e-positive if when expanded in terms of the elementary symmetric function basis, its coefficients are polynomials with positive integer coefficients.

This project was mainly concerned with e-positivities arising in the theory of modified Macdonald polynomials and their related symmetric function operators. This involved three main aspects: the study of the Nabla, Delta, and Theta operators along with their algebraic relations, the study of the representation theoretic interpretation of these symmetric function expressions, and the combinatorial models which describe the expansions of these symmetric functions in terms of some classical basis. 

The algebra of operators generated by the Nabla, Delta, and Theta operators plays an important role in a variety of subjects such as knot theory and algebraic geometry. Through the course of this work, we developed tools that help deal with expressions involving these operators and applied them to prove several connections between these symmetric function operators and certain representation theoretical structures. One is the diagonal, fermionic coinvariants, where, in joint work with Iraci and Rhoades, we showed that Theta operators indeed give the Frobenius characteristic of the bigraded character for the coinvariants in two sets of anti-commuting variables. This verified a special case of a conjecture of D'Adderio, Iraci, and Vanden Wyngaerd. In joint work with D'Adderio, Iraci, Le Borgne, and Vanden Wyngaerd, we find that Theta operators have further connections to representations of certain quivers and their Kac polynomials.

On the combinatorial side, we found vast families of symmetric function expressions (involving Theta and Delta operators) that exhibit what we call the e-positivity phenomenon. In joint work with Iraci, we introduced a new family of labeled parallelogram polyominoes, which we call gamma-Parking Functions; and we showed that these polyominoes give a combinatorial model for applications of Delta and Theta operators when one of the parameters (q or t) are set to 1. We conjecture that these symmetric functions exhibit the e-positivity phenomenon, meaning that gamma-Parking Functions should themselves give the e-expansion for these symmetric functions with no specialization. 

 Lastly, we introduce a new symmetric function operator which we call Super Nabla and is indexed by any algebraic expression. This operator, when applied to a symmetric function, can create a multi-symmetric function; and when specialized, it is able to recover many (if not all) of the aforementioned symmetric functions. We introduce a new set of combinatorial objects called gamma,kn-Parking Functions, and we show that when one parameter is set to 1, these new labeled parallelogram polyominoes provide the e-expansion for iterated applications of the Super Nabla operator. We apply these operators to both elementary symmetric functions and power sum symmetric functions, finding e-positivities in both cases.

The work from this project suggests that labeled parallelogram polyominoes give a universal combinatorial model for understanding applications of Delta, Theta, and now Super Nabla operators. Through the e-positivity phenomenon, we get that these combinatorial models should give e-expansions for the unspecialized symmetric functions. Such an expansion would be a remarkable development in the theory of symmetric functions. With new connections to representation theory and the representations of quivers, we believe this phenomenon has a deeper significance with many directions for future research.


Last Modified: 01/28/2024
Modified by: Marino Romero
